"Like a corner of the Orient dropped down into the midst of the Occident, the Japanese Garden with its lily pond at Overton Park, is a vivid splotch of color. It is as fragrant as it is lovely. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Overton Park Pavilion and Lake with High Fountain
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Pavilion and Lake, Overton Park, Memphis, Tenn." Color image with high spray from fountain.

"Mrs. Maria S. Ellis -- 739 Madison St. -- Clarksville -- Tenn. -- Dear Mrs. Ellis, -- Did you reach home safely? -- We had a most delightful time in -- Chatt. We three girls went together, -- did not care to stay with the other -- bunch. Did you find a bracelet -- in your room? The night I came -- in (Fri.) I took off my jewelery (?) some -- in your room and some in mine. -- Well, anyway I got to the train and my -- bracelet was not on my arm so thought -- I left it in the room. Have not found it -- among my things. -- Barbara Leronin -- 1133 E. Moreland."

"Miss Wilma Keith, -- 2179 Ocean Ave., -- Brooklyn, -- N.Y. -- Memphis, Tenn., -- I heard that you -- have been very sick and -- I do hope that you are -- better. I suppose that -- you are anxiously wait- -- ing for the time to start -- back to school if you -- will be able to go. I have -- been having such a fine -- time that I am sorry for -- the time to come. Have you -- seen Marguerite? I -- hope that I will hear -- from you soon. -- Ruth"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Davies Plantation Manor
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color image.

“Davies Manor -- 9336 Davies Plantation Rd., Brunswick, Shelby County, TN 38014 -- A two-story log colonial house built in part by an Indian chief before 1807. For many years the plantation home of brothers Logan E. and James B. Davies. Owned by Davies Manor Association, Inc. Headquarters for three hereditary-patriotic organizations: Zachariah Davies Chapter, NS., DAR; Old Stage Road Society, NS., CAR; Shelby Chapter, NS., SAR. Placed on the National Register of Historic Places, 1975.”

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Approaching the Wharf from the Mississippi River
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: “Approaching the Wharf, Memphis, Tenn. -- Memphis – July 29/09 [handwritten]” Color image taken from the river with buildings in background.

“Mrs. Frank A. Drake -- Springfield -- Ill. -- 871 So. Lincoln Ave. -- Hello all – Here is where we landed -- at 6 tonight, but in a much larger boat -- than shown here. Had a delightful -- trip and ful time – Leave for Earl, -- Ark. at 9 tomorrow. Fearfully hot tonight -- in Memphis. This is a great city. Get back -- here Sunday. Take boat Monday noon. -- Will call here for mail at gen. del. Monday -- but don’t write unless necessary. FAS”

“Ms. J. M. Everitt -- 5737 Amelia Ave. -- St. Louis, MO. -- So glad to get your -- letter. Hope the cold -- is all gone. Plenty -- cold here. Will go -- home Sat. & write -- from there. Lots -- of love to all, -- Mary. -- Southwestern, the College of the Mississippi Valley. This is Memphis’ first college of liberal arts. Located on a beautiful wooded campus on North Parkway, opposite Overton Park, the buildings of vari-colored stone are among the first examples of college architecture in the United States.”

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: “Sunken Garden and Entrance to Morningside Park on the Parkway, Memphis, Tenn.” Color image.

“Mrs. J. W. Everett -- 916 West 13th -- Pine Bluff, -- Arkansas -- Dearest Mona – Just to let -- you know we are think- -- ing of you. Mr. LeRoy is -- home this week as the -- place he had “changed -- hands” sat. Ms. Katy calling out. -- He is resting a day or two -- before taking another steady -- job. Plans to open up something -- the middle of March or -- a little sooner. I’ve written -- Mil a note & sent 2 “get well” cards -- twice. Hope she is better. Drop -- me a card. Take care of yourself -- Lots o love, -- Eliz”

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: PeeWee's Saloon on Beale
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color image reproduction of watercolor painting of PeeWee’s Saloon.

“Goodwyn Institute -- May 17 1957 -- Institute -- Birthplace of the ‘Blues’ -- Beale Street Memphis -- It was in a back corner of Pee Wee’s Place on a night in 1909 that W.C. Handy tuned up his band and wailed out the first ‘Blues’ ever to be written. He’d written it for a hot political campaign and named it the ‘Mr. Crump’ song. Mr. Crump won the election and Handy rode on his song from Beale to Broadway. Later changed to the ‘Memphis Blues,’ a flood of rhythm went pulsating across the country, to Paris, to Singapore. W.C. Handy had given to the world the ‘Blues’ … the child born of his genius in a back corner of PeeWee’s Place on Beale Street.”

“Dr. and Mrs. T. P. Nash -- c/o Nags Header Hotel -- Nags Head, North Carolina -- Hi! -- This is just to remind you -- of the 'salt mines.' Dorothy -- still with us for another week. -- I delivered phone bill & returned -- skirts so relax! Be sure & get -- the C’s to climb Jockey’s Ridge. -- Love to all. Thanks for cards from -- Chimney Rock. -- Peg”

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Aerial photo view of city taken from the west

“Memphis, Tennessee -- Memphis-on-the-Mississippi River is the social, cultural, and economic capital of the Mid-South. A wholesaling, retailing, manufacturing, and transportation center, Memphis is the world’s largest spot cotton market and world’s largest inland hardwood market. Here too are six colleges and a great medical center. 1958 population by special U. S. Census was 488,500”

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: “General Nathan Bedford Forrest at Bogler’s Creek, Alabama,” color image.

“Memphis Portraits – Forrest, Nathan Bedford [Handwritten] The last personal encounter of the Confederate General Nathan Bedford Forrest, April 1, 1865, at Ebenezer Church on Bogler’s Creek, twenty miles North of Selma, Ala., his opponent Capt. Jas. Taylor, 17th Indiana. Post-War railroad building took Gen. Forrest to Arkansas, where one of his camps became Forrest City. The painting was executed by Frederick Ruple at Batesville, Ark. for V. Y. Cook who served in Forrest’s Cavalry. [typed/pre-printed] -- Cossitt Library -- Jul 30 1965 -- Memphis, Tenn.”

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Chucalissa Museum Exterior
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Chucalissa Museum Exterior, color image.

“Museum Building - Chucalissa Pre-Historic Indian Town -- This famous Archaeological Ruin – now a State Park – is under development by an archeologist, and is open to public the year ‘round. (Closed on Mondays). It is thought that this ancient town was once occupied by Indians very much like the Chickasaw and Choctaw as they were first known to Europeans. The town itself was an important ceremonial center. Located west of U. S. Highway 61, just south of Memphis, Tennessee. For additional information, write: Division Of State Parks, Cordell Hull Bldg., Nashville 3, Tennessee”

“River-Rail-Truck Terminal -- Memphis, Tennessee -- This new $1,500,000 public terminal on industrialized Presidents Island has four unloading points, providing modern facilities for the handling of cargo from Mississippi River barges direct to railroad cars or trucks. 5 ½ -million tons of freight are shipped in and out of the Port of Memphis each year.”

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: “Field of Cotton in Bloom, Memphis, Tenn.” Color image.

“Miss Jane Doe, -- Anywhere, -- Yoube -- Memphis, Tenn. -- This is to tell you about -- ’Plantation Jewelry.’ -- It is hand made and is copied -- from the baskets used in the cotton fields, filled with seed cotton -- just as it is picked, dyed bright or -- pastel colors and worn with play, -- town, dinner or dancing clothes, -- it adds just that subtle, flattering -- effect that the right accessories -- create. -- Can be had in lapel ornaments, -- ear rings, barrettes, necklaces, -- studs and bracelets. -- If you want colored cotton ask -- for it where you bought this. -- Alice Odeneal.”

I took off me jewelry (?) some -- in your room and some in mine. -- Well, anyway I got to the train and my -- bracelet was not on my arm so thought -- I left it in the room. Have not found it -- among my things. -- Barbara Leronin -- 1133 E. Moreland."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Magevney House
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three different views of the Magevney House, Color image.

“Souvenir Folder of Magevney House -- Memphis -- Magevney House, Memphis, Tenn. Home of Eugene Magevney, pioneer schoolmaster, was built in 1831. Mr. Magevney was born September 15, 1798, in County Fermanagh, Sessiagh, Ireland. His American citizenship was granted him in Lebanon County, Penn., August 17, 1833. In that year he came to Memphis where he taught school in a log cabin on the site which is now Court Square. He bought the historic residence on Adams Avenue in 1837. Mary Smyth, native of Sessiagh also and a former pupil, journeyed from Ireland to become his bride and they were married May 31, 1840 in this house, theirs being the first Catholic marriage in Memphis. Already in 1839 the first Catholic Mass had been said here on an Altar improvised upon a mahogany bureau. True to his Irish heritage, he preferred the charm of his first simple fireside to the mansion which his fortune could have provided in later years. One pasture tract was given him by Mr. Robertson Topp as a tuition payment. Today Schoolmaster Magevney’s pasture is under Main and Union Streets. Mr. Magevney died September 30, 1873 of yellow fever at the age of seventy-five. Restored and maintained by Memphis Park Commission.”
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Magevney House; residences; Main Street; Union Avenue; downtown; parks;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis Belle
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Memphis Belle" with color image of plane. Eight signatures of crew members: Harold Loch, Top Turret; Bill Winchell, Left Waist Gunner; Eugene Adkins, Ball Turret; Robt. Typed: "The Memphis Belle is a B-17 'flying fortress' that completed 25 missions over German occupied Europe during WWII. This famous plane is now on permanent display at Mud Island in Memphis, Tennessee. Named for Margaret Polk, whom pilot Robert K. Morgan met during the war, the Belle is a stirring reminder of those who fought so bravely in WWII. The Memphis Belle is on loan from the United States Air Force Museum to the Memphis Belle Memorial Association." -- Stamped: "Frank G. Donofrio -- 5647 Hinton Pl. Cove -- Memphis, TN 38119"
